title: the hairy harasser
story: NewsTHE HAIRY HARASSERThis man reduced elderly community councillors to tearsShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHe incensed French villagers to the extent they formed a -strong mob and the mayor accused him of terrorising his neighbours. Now Robert Dunlop has gained a criminal conviction for terrorising the people of Troon. The former Troon butcher, who turns  on April Fool’s Day, waged a letter vendetta against seven members of Troon Community Council. This reduced some community councillors to tears and one woman was so terried she now has a police panic alarm. Dunlop, of A Barassie Street, Troon, was found guilty on Friday by Sherf Scott Pattison of causing fear and alarm but not guilty of having a lock kne in Dundonald Road. His partner Krystyna Domanska, , was also on trial but was cleared of any involvement. Both had denied conducting the campaign between October  and September . Dunlop escaped with a slap on the wrist and has been warned to be of good behaviour for the next six months. His bail conditions banning him from approaching any of the community councillors will remain in place. This week a Troon Community Council spokesperson said: “We are very unhappy at the sentence but glad this man is now a convicted criminal. “He upset so many lovely volunteers in Troon and put us through the ordeal of having to give evidence in court. “It has been a very stressful time and we are all delighted this is now over.” Dozens of threatening letters were delivered to the home addresses of the community councillors. It was sparked when Dunlop lost the plot with the then South Ayrshire councillor Nan McFarlane, who had tried to help him in a benefits issue. The letters claimed the community councillors were involved in corruption, fraud and assault. Dunlop threatened to inform the public of this and claimed he was entitled to “bear arms and inflict violence”. The Ayrshire Post also received a nine-page letter, quoting an ancient Roman law called the Augustine Petition as the basis for the hostility. One y diatribe claimed all  South Ayrshire councillors were corrupt without providing any evidence. Other letters were despatched to South Ayrshire’s chief executive, legal head Ralph Riddiough, Troon police and the chief constable. Churches were also sent letters in a bid to blacken the names of citizens. Dunlop and Domanska made national headlines five years ago when the French village they were living in turned against them. They were accused of being neighbours from hell after building a wall, preventing the popular couple next door using their front door and nailing down their window shutters. The village mayor said the neighbours had been “terrorised” and Dunlop sent a -page letter to the French justice minister and an -page epic to then president Nicolas Sarkozy.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnTroonScotlands CommunityAyrAyr News

title: thieving girvan florist ordered cough
story: NewsThieving Girvan florist ordered to cough upLaurenson was lucky to escape jail when sentenced at Ayr Sherf Court in February .ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsAnnabel Laurenson appeared at Ayr Sherf Court"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA thieving florist has made just one repayment on £ compensation ordered by a court, writes Edwin Lawrence. That was for £ - and was made over a year ago, Ayr Sherf Court heard. Yet social media pages during that time show Annabel Laurenson on days out all over south-west Scotland. They also show a new family car and pay-to-view sports channels in her family home. Laurenson was lucky to escape jail when sentenced at Ayr Sherf Court in February . She admitted stealing from the Nicola Jayne Flowers business in Girvan on dates between January ,  and December , . Laurenson was ordered to complete  hours of unpaid work, and to pay back £ in compensation to her former bosses. The total value of cash and goods she stole was estimated at much more than this figure.    And the hurt and distress caused to her former employers, who were also her friends, can’t be quantied. Defence lawyer John Gallagher last week told Ayr Sherf Court that Laurenson, , had completed her unpaid work. But he admitted the only repayment she has made was the £ she turned up at court with - on the day of her sentence in February last year. Mr Gallagher claimed Laurenson, of Girvan’s Maxwell Street, had hoped to secure a loan from her father. But he died in November, and the costs of his care and his funeral made this impossible. “She is unemployed, but her husband is in work, and she is well aware this has to be repaid,” said Mr Gallagher. The lawyer said the remainder of Laurenson’s father’s estate would have to be shared with her mother and siblings. “How much is she likely to inherit ” asked Sherf John Montgomery. “I’m not sure,” said Mr Gallagher. “But not enough to pay this back.”    “The time for repayment has lapsed,” said Sherf Montgomery bluntly. Mr Gallagher insisted that Laurenson was anxious to pay the outstanding £. He asked the sherf to revoke the original payback order, and instruct a new compensation order. Mr Gallagher said Laurenson could pay £ per month, and Sherf Montgomery agreed to the request. Laurenson had worked at the popular Dalyrmple Street business for many years, and was a trusted member of staff. Shop owner Nicola Jayne Purdie said she was ‘devastated’ to find out her colleague and friend was ripping her off. She said at the time of last year’s sentence: “She stole a substantial amount of money and stock. There has been absolutely no remorse. She hasn’t said sorry. I feel betrayed. This is a family business and we were working together for  years.”Nicola Jayne said the theft came to light after she noticed discrepancies within the business. Laurenson who shared family occasions with the Purdies, including parties, weddings and funerals, offered no explanation for her behaviour.

title: unpaid-work-and-curfew-for-41-year-old-for-ae-and-pub-disturbances
story: A GALASHIELS man who caused a disturbance in a public house and was also disruptive at Borders General Hospital has been ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work at Selkirk Sherf Court.Simon Hadden was also given a four-months night time home curfew and ordered to pay a total of pound in compensation to four women he was abusive towards.The -year-old pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner at the Bridge Inn in Galashiels on October  and struggling violently with police officers.The court was told that Hadden had been drinking in the pub and at about .am he started to abuse two female customers with ious insults.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said that the accused was looking to get a reaction from customers and continued making insults.He refused to leave the premises on three occasions but eventually did after abusing a female bar staff member.When three police officers arrived on the scene he was also abusive towards them including a female constable.Hadden suffered a bump on the head during a struggle and had to be taken to hospital for a check-up but on the journey constantly kicked the interior of the vehicle.Mr Fraser said: "He was abusive in the hospital which was busy at the time and was shouting and swearing referring to paedophiles and rapists. "He was told to keep the noise down."After another struggle with police officers he was cautioned and charged and in his statement he was again abusive and threatened one officer by sayinghe saw him in the street he was going to kick his head in.Defence lawyer Ross Dow explained that the reference to paedophiles and rapists came up because he was complaining that he was being arrested and was alleging that no action was being taken against a former neighbour.He continued: "He does know this is a serious matter. His father had just passed away and he ended up drinking too much."Sherf Peter Paterson said the behaviour merited a custodial sentence but added he could impose the alternative.But he warned: "If you are back before the court again because of your drinking, you will be jailed."Hadden was given a  months Community Pay Back Order with supervision,  hours unpaid work and a four months Restriction of Liberty Order at his Hawthorn Road home between the hours of pm and .am.In addition he was told to pay pound compensation to each of the four women - the two customers, the bar employee and the police constable - he subjected to abusive comments.

title: borders-chef-michael-hoping-to-follow-in-famous-footsteps
story: A CHEF from the Borders has made it to the final of a prestigious cooking competition after impressing celebrity judges with his culinary skills.Michael Cruickshank, who grew up in Newtown, will join five other talented young chefs from some of the countryrsquos finest eateries in the Roux Scholarship National Final on Monday, April .The winner of the scholarship, founded by chefs Albert and Michel Roux in , will receive training in a three-star Michelin restaurant.The Roux Scholarship, which funds all expenses, also provides the winner with the opportunity to travel across the world and a pound, bursary for professional development.Michael, who previously made the final of the competition in , currently works at the Michelin-starred restaurant Bohemia, in Jersey.Having come so close two years ago, he is looking to go one better this year.He told The Border : ldquoAfter getting to the final in , I see getting to the final is the minimum level I want to aim for.ldquoItrsquos been a crazy couple of weeks with a mixture of nerves and excitement.ldquoI had loads of help from my head chef, who gave me time to practise and take time out to come here today.ldquoAs Michel Roux Jr said, you canrsquot do it without people helping you.Michael made it to the final after wowing the judges with his interpretation of the competition brief, with a recipe utilising roasted hogget loin with hogget kidneys in a haggis-inspired faggot.The judges at the regional final, held in London, were impressed by the levels of creativity, technical skill and knowledge displayed by the chefs.Renowned chef Michael Roux Jr, one of the judges who sent Michael through to the national final, described the ldquoamazing standard on display. He said: ldquoEvery year it just gets better and better the correctness of the cooking and the seasoning was beyond reproach.Previous winners have gone on to earn multiple Michelin stars and international acclaim.Andrew Fairlie, who died earlier this year, won the inaugural scholarship before opening the only Scottish restaurant to receive two Michelin stars.He previously spoke of the scholarshiprsquos impact on his career, saying: ldquoWhen I was encouraged by my chef Keith Podmore to enter this new competition that the Roux brothers had started back in , I had no idea the huge influence the scholarship would have on my career and le.ldquoI can honestly say that I would not have been as successfulI had not won the scholarship and all the support it has given me over the years.

title: dominoes-ace-norman-leaves-the-rest-chapping
story: THEY like their doubles at Nikis Bar.Not only did mine host Norman Mciver leave the rest chapping as he claimed the Galashiels Dominoes League coveted Piper Cup - for most inidual wins over the season - but he was also part of the winning league team.The win comes on the back of Nikis Numpties claiming the overall Galashiels Dominoes League title.But perhaps the most remarkable win of the dominoes season came at Gala Bowling Club.The knock-out finals featured the hosts, the British Legion, the Ladhope and Gala Fairydean Rovers.Despite trailing - in the semi-final Gala Bowling Club won six in a row to progress.And it was a similar story in the final against the Ladhope where they came from - down to win -.

title: serving-up-safety-is-celebrated-at-best-bar-none
story: PUBS, restaurants and hotels were recognised for serving up safety at the Best Bar None awards ceremony this week.Held at the Buccleuch Arms hotel in St Boswells, representatives from  licensed premises were rewarded for their commitment to making a night out that little bit better.And businesses from Eddleston to Eyemouth all received a gong, with the Queens Head in Kelso also in the running for a national award.Councillor John Greenwell, chairman of the Scottish Borders Licensing Board, who presented the awards, said: ldquoItrsquos really reassuring to see our bars taking customer care and safety seriously, which is what Best Bar None is all about.ldquoI congratulate all of our worthy winners and also wish the Queens Head the best of luck in the national finals.The prizes are broken into three level ndash gold, silver and bronze depending on how well a premises met the Best Bar None criteria.This yearrsquos gold winners were: Barony Castle , Buccleuch Arms Hotel , The Carters Rest , The Cobbles Inn , Coopers Bar , Liddesdale Hotel , Melrose Rugby Club, Oblo , The Plough Hotel , The Queenrsquos Head Hotel , Templehall Hoteland Town Arms Inn .The silver winners were: The Bridge Inn , The Cross Keys , Dryburgh Abbey Hotel and The Tavern Bar .The bronze winners were: The Bourtreeand Hunterrsquos Hall .Each premise is now accredited to the Best Bar None scheme.The Best Bar None Awards is supported by the Scottish Government, Scottish Borders Council, Police Scotland and Scottish Fire and Rescue Service.PC Nick Walker from the Scottish Borders Safer Communities Team and local Best Bar None lead, added: "We are grateful to everyone who took part in Best Bar None and it was great to see everyone getting their awards."Wersquore already looking ahead to this yearrsquos scheme, which will launch in the coming weeks, and I hope we can get even for premises signed up."For more information contact the Safer Communities Team on   or safercommunities@scotborders.gov.uk.

title: borders-set-for-role-in-digital-future-of-produce-markets
story: THE Scottish Borders is one of four Scottish regions set to share in pound, of EU funding, after a project to roll out click and collect farmersrsquo markets across rural Scotland was given the green light.Forth Environment Link, which runs Stirling NeighbourFood, will use the six-figure grant to establish eight new weekly markets across the Scottish Borders, Perth and Kinross, Forth Valley and Loch Lomond and Fe by .The NeighbourFood project aims to increase rural access to Scotlandrsquos larder by creating rural employment, offering small scale producers a safe route to market and connecting shoppers with the people who make or grow food locally.After registering for free, shoppers can place an order online using the NeighbourFood  and pick it up from a central venue ndash in Stirlingrsquos case, a local High School.The funding comes from a collaboration between four Scottish Rural Network LEADER programmes, as part of a wider EU funding programme aimed at supporting grassroots development of rural communities and businesses through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.As well as cutting down on waste, the initiative should see local producers rewarded fairly for their work.Jack Crotty, Director of NeighbourFood, explained how the model dfers from large retailers. He said: ldquoOur producers set their own prices and get to keep  percent of sales for every product, compared to - percent through supermarkets.ldquoThe remaining  percent is split equally between the market host and NeighbourFood.Since launching in Stirling in , the market has boosted the local economy by pound,, with producers keeping most of the profits.There is optimism in the Borders that the rollout of the project into the region will benefit the public as well as producers.Jane Rosegrant, Scottish Borders Leader Action Group Chair, said: ldquoScottish Borders LEADER is delighted to be supporting this innovative approach to making local food more accessible to local people.ldquoAt a time when sustainabilitymdashboth environmental and economicmdashis more important than ever, this project provides a practical way to provide fresh produce, cut food miles and support local producers all at the same time.The hunt is now on for eight new market hosts, who will be given funding, training and promotional support to set up the NeighbourFood scheme in their own area.Interested parties can register their interest in the scheme by contacting stuart@forthenvironmentlink.org.

title: borders-gardens-set-for-blooming-marvellous-festival
story: TWO Borders Gardens are set to show off their horticultural delights as they take part in this yearrsquos Scottish Rhododendron Festival.Dawyck Botanic Garden and Abbotsford will be representing the Borders in the annual festival, ing for its fth year, which runs from April  to May .The Scottish Rhododendron Festival is organised by national garden tourism group Discover Scottish Gardens, with support from VisitScotland, and comprises more than fty events across the country.Dawyck Botanic Garden, described by VisitScotland as ldquoa delight for Rhododendron enthusiasts, features an array of specimens gathered from the wild, with some now over  years old.Abbotsford, the ancestral home of Sir Walter Scott, will be running exclusive tours for the festival between May  and May .Paula Ward, VisitScotland Regional Leadership Director, hopes the participation of the two gardens will be of benefit to the entire region. She said: ldquoIrsquom thrilled to see that Dawyck Botanic Garden and Abbotsford are taking part in the Scottish Rhododendron Festival.ldquoWith the weather getting warmer, visitors will be able to see this magnicent plant flower as well as enjoy all that these attractions have to offer.ldquoThese visitors represent a major benefit to the region.ldquoTourism is more than a holiday experience, it is the heartbeat of the Scottish economy and touches every community, generating income, jobs and social change.Borderers may already have noticed an abundance of flowering Rhododendrons, with many species flowering early this year due to unseasonably warm weather.David Knott, curator at the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh, a world centre for rhododendron studies, said: ldquoThe warmer temperatures we have been experiencing provide optimum conditions for these exotic shrubs, originally from the East, to thrive.ldquoThe unusual weather and early flowering also highlight the impact of climate change on plants and flowering behaviour - a situation we will continue to monitor at the Botanics.

title: scotrail-cancellations-due-to-wrong-kind-of-staff
story: MSP Christine Grahame has criticised ScotRailrsquos lack of foresight relating to workforce planning after it emerged that a spate of recent cancellations was the result of a lack of trained staff.The CEO of ScotRail Abellio, Alex Hynes, was appearing before Holyroodrsquos Rural Economy and Connectivity Committee after the operator faced heavy criticism in the wake of numerous delays and cancellations.He was speaking to the committee following the publication of an pound million remedial plan, in response to being issued with an improvement notice by the Scottish Government in December because of low levels of passenger satisfaction.A further improvement notice was issued in February following multiple cancellations of services due to ongoing staffing issues.In the remedial plan ScotRail concedes that ldquothe service our customers have received has not been good enough recently and that the operator ldquoaccepts ultimate responsibility for the unacceptable service our customers have received.Mr Hynes announced that the recent cancellations ldquowere not due to not having enough train crew but instead ldquothey were due to not having enough train crew trained in the new routes and the new types of train.During the questioning it emerged that the operator had not previously employed anyone with overall responsibility for workforce planning.The Borders railway passes through Ms Grahamersquos constituency, and has been badly affected by recent service disruptions, with the MSP staggered by the apparent lack of planning.She said: ldquoIt would appear that ScotRail have recruited sufficient staff ndash indeed they currently have  applicants for driver roles ndash but have completely failed in planning for what routes theyrsquoll be needed on and when theyrsquoll be trained on them.ldquoThis is made all the clearer by the fact there has been no-one with overall responsibility for workforce planning, which is frankly astounding.ldquoI accept they have said they will now introduce this as a role, and that the new timetable was planned before the current CEO took charge, but I cannot imagine my Borders and Midlothian constituents, and passengers across Scotland, will be overly impressed at this lack of basic planning.ldquoMr Hynesrsquo explanation that they had enough staff, but not enough staff trained, rather brings to mind the lsquowrong kind of leavesrsquo on the line ndash only this time they had the wrong kind of staff.

title: innerleithen-opera-make-a-habit-of-great-shows
story: All is right in the kingdom of Innerleithen as the amazing Opera cast get back in the habit of raising the roof off the Memorial Hall with their stage adaptation of Sister Act.Its opening night for Innerleithen  District Operatic Society who are about to debut the musical comedy that hit our screens in .When clubland a Deloris Van Cartier played by Nicola Watt burst into song with her big hair, leopard print clothes and purple knee high boots, I was hooked.The story echoes that of the movie. Deloris is a Philadelphia lounge singer who dreams of stardom, but when she witnesses her lover-turned-gangster shoot one of his mob, she flees into the arms of good guy cop lsquoSweaty Eddiersquo .Delorisrsquo world is turned upside down when she is placed under witness protection in a rundown convent, disguised as nun Sister Mary Clarence.Although the adaptation does not feature songs from the original film, the musical repertoire is erse and magical.When we first catch a glimpse of the nuns, as they meander across the stage squawking like a bunch of demented penguins, I grimace. They are so out of tune I pray I donrsquot hear that god awful sound again.Upon learning that Deloris will be joining the convent, Mother Superior, played by Pam Graham, prays: ldquoDear Lordthis is a test, I cannot fail with you by my side. May she be of faith, of modestyhellip But she is stopped in her tracks by the voice of a brash American Deloris.Mother Superior continues: ldquoPerhaps the choir of angels drowned me out and you didnrsquot hear me Lord.Pam plays the exasperated Mother Superior prissy and clipped, with subtle comedy delivered in perfect tone.Of course things donrsquot run smoothly for the ghetto-fabulous a-turned-nun as you probably can imagine. It isnrsquot long before Deloris ruffles Mother Superiorrsquos habit and puts the nuns in danger, which leads to Deloris being given just one simple activity, joining the choir.Can she really unleash the songbirds trapped inside these nuns  This is when the show steps up a notch, and, although all dressed in habits, the audience can start to identy with the lead characters.In steps jolly Sister Mary Patrick, played by the enigmatic Claire Bell, along with Sister Mary Robertas the timid church mouse, and deadpan choir director Sister Mary Lazaruswho fully captured the gravelly voiced cantankerous nun. Her reprisal of the screen character is uncanny and garners lots of laughs from the audience.When the large ensemble of nuns gathered together, I did feel a sense of sisterhood and that they were each playing dferent characters despite having a minor role or no dialogue. Their pitch perfect delivery of lsquoRaise Your Voicersquo and lsquoTake Me To Heavenrsquo would draw the crowds into any church Irsquom sure.Playing the leading lady is no easy task, but in scene after scene Nicola embraces Deloris and puts her own sass and ghetto style into the character, belting out powerful tunes. To sum up her performance, what better words to use than those of Deloris Van Cartier herself ndash shersquos lsquoFabulous Babyrsquo!The last time I saw Lizzie Bell she was stumbling about drunk and shouting at a group of young kids, so I was shocked to see her convert to a Catholic nun. Of course, Lizzie was in character then as the vile orphanage boss Miss Hannigan, for Annie, performed by the Kids Innerleithen Theatre in November last year. The young actress shows true ersity, by portraying the meek Sister Mary Roberts with an enchanting solo performance.Although the female performances were powerful, they did not overshadow the male cast. Roger Brydon, Stewart Wilson and Colin Tweedie had me in tears as bumbling henchmen Joey, TJ and Pablo. Their comical performance of lsquoLady In The Long Black Dressrsquo didnrsquot leave females in the audience weak at the knees, but it did conjure up a few belly laughs!David Paterson was cast as Curtis who played the mob boss brilliantly, dominating the stage fiercely. And mild mannered officer Eddie Souterwho gave a cracking solo, proves he lsquoCould Be That Guyrsquo going from lsquoSweaty Eddiersquo to lsquoCool Copper, saving Deloris and winning her heart. A special mention to Jamie McCubbin, as the Irish Monsignor OrsquoHara ndashI closed my eyes Irsquod swear it was Father Ted!Needless to say the cast were at the top of their game, but anyone going to the show will no doubt be dazzled by the glitzy backdrop and detailed stained glass art of the fictional Catholic church. And the sensational costumes had more sparkle than a disco ballhellipand for habits, thatrsquos no mean feat.Sister Act had the congregation of the Memorial Hall hailing Hallelujah and taking us all to heaven, with what I can only sum up as a musical godsend.

title: asdas-arrival-drove-wilderhaugh-to-become-best-in-scotland
story: A GALASHIELS petrol station is officially the best in Scotland.And the boss of Shells Wilderhaugh Filling Station admits it was the arrival of supermarket competition which drove his company to success.Wilderhaughs retail manager Richard Garrie collected the Scottish Large Forecourt of the Year trophy during the Forecourt Trader Awards in London.Richard described his firms fightback following the arrival of a local supermarket four years ago, which knocked fuel volumes by  percent overnight.He said: "We thought long and hard about how to tackle this."We realised that one thing we can offer our customers that a local supermarket cant, is good old-fashioned service."Even before Shell did it we put our own local attendants back on the forecourt and customers really appreciated it."We also launched a ppl-off fuel promotion for six months, which meant we were ppl cheaper than the local Asda."The promotion is linked to buying a car wash, and has been so successful we still run it occasionally. Its essential to always create a buzz around the business."An pound, shop refit and the introduction of Spar three years ago has also helped boost business.Charity and promotional events such as Lucky Pump Day, run in conjunction with Cash for Kids, has also helped put Wilderhaugh on the map.The site has just re-signed with Shell for five years and has just raised its canopy to . metres to attract bigger vehicles used by local businesses.Richard added: "What a great honour it was to collect the award on behalf of the staff at Adam Purves. Weve been totally blown away by winning this award. Its a great boost for the guys, and recognition for everything weve achieved."Our Forecourt Trader award was in recognition for the passion and quality of service delivered by our team. We now have a site that matches this in appearance."

title: selkirk-booze-thief-has-sentence-deferred
story: A -year-old Selkirk man admitted stealing alcohol from a local shop he is banned from.James Birchall of Sentry Knowe pleaded guilty to stealing three bottles of spirits from the Co-operative store in High Street, Selkirk, last month and breaching his bail conditions.Sentence was deferred at Selkirk Sherf Court until May .

title: council-offers-upset-grave-families-loan-of-lifting-equipment
story: AN elderly Peebles couple claim they have been offered the lsquoloan of a lting machinersquo by the local authority after complaining about their family headstone being toppled.As previously reported, more than  headstones were taken down during a safety inspection earlier this year.And the majority of the memorials were lsquosocketedrsquo into the ground by the inspectors.Dozens of families have raised the concerns and made complaints to Scottish Borders Council over the destruction ndash among them are Richard and Kay Learmond A memorial plaque for Richardrsquos sister, Betty, who died in New Zealand was placed onto the family headstone.But following a recent visit to the cemetery they were shocked to find the memorial had been dismantled and lsquosocketedrsquo with the memorial plaque buried beneath ground.After making a complaint, the pensioners claim they were told they would have to lsquocorrect the headstonersquo themselves and they could borrow a lting machine.Kay told us: ldquoWe have never complained about anything before but this is awful.ldquoWhen we made our first complaint the girl from the council offered us the loan of a lting machine so we could correct the headstone - she added that they couldnrsquot pay for the damage.ldquoWersquove made a second complaint but havenrsquot heard back yet.The memorial plaque for Richardrsquos sister was originally on a wall at a cemetery in Dunedin.But when authorities in New Zealand planned to demolish the wall for expansion purposes the family decided it should be placed on the headstone of her parents, George and Mary, in Peebles.Kay told us: ldquoWe werenrsquot aware there was anything wrong with the headstone -we had, wersquod have had it sorted.ldquoIt was a lovely granite headstone, yet it has been desecrated.ldquoThe first we knew of this was when we went to visit the grave. It has been very upsetting.A total of  headstones were tested in Peebles Cemetery with  deemed unsafe during the five-weeks inspection.Among the many stones which have been lsquomade safersquo are memorials to babies and soldiers killed in the wars.Local MSP Christine Grahame has hit out at the treatment of Mr and Mrs Learmond as well as others who have been left distressed by the inspection.She told us: ldquoI understand the need to ensure headstones at cemeteries are safe but the way this was handled by the council was insensitive and in some cases badly deliveredldquoI have seen the way the headstone at Mr and Mrs Learmondrsquos family lair was ed - the engraved plaque buried crudely and unnecessarily ldquoI trust it will be properly reinstated and the family receive an apology from the council.ldquoThis is not the first and probably not the last time Scottish Border Council has failed to inform and consult my constituents and its time it learned to do so.,params: .pushScottish Borders Council is responsible for health and safety obligations to all employees, contractors and visitors to each of the graveyards.Although headstones are the responsibility of the lair-holder, due to the age of many graves tracing families is dficult.And a five-year rolling programme of safety checks began in September.The local authority claims it is only offering lting equipment when stonemasons are employed to restore the memorials.A spokesperson said: ldquoAs part of the headstone safety testing programme to ensure a series of cemeteries are safe for people to visit and work in, Mr Learmondrsquos family headstone in Peebles Cemetery was made safe by socketing ndash a technique which keeps the headstone upright with the majority of the inscription still visible for families and visitors to read.ldquoMr Learmond indicated he would contact a monumental mason to re-erect the headstone and we advised our staff could assist by lting the headstone out of the socket in preparation for the memorial being fully restored by the mason.

title: historic-sites-in-the-scottish-borders-open-for-the-summer
story: Historical sites in the Scottish Borders are reopening now for the summer season.Historic Environment Scotland , which manages over  historical properties in Scotland and  in the Borders, has launched its events programme for the summer .Hermitage Castle, with its murky stories of the past and its beautul wildle, and Smailholm Tower, known for the stunning views that inspired Sir Walter Scottrsquos, will open the doors for the season on Monday  April.Dryburgh Abbey will host a Easter Eggsplorer Trail over the Easter weekend, when visitors will be given clues to complete challenges, while exploring the iconic structure.You can get your tickets for the Easter trail in advance online and save % or get them directly on the day. Historic Scotland members enter for free.Stephen Duncan, Director of Commercial  Tourism at HES, said: ldquoThe start of the season is always an exciting time for us, as we get ready to welcome new and ing visitors to our sites across the country, including the Borders.ldquoAt Historic Environment Scotland we are passionate about being able to provide experiences that allow locals and visitors to explore Scotlandrsquos rich heritage. Our  schedule offers a great way to discover Scotlandrsquos past, and wersquore really looking forward to welcoming everyone to our venues across the Borders and further afield.You can check out the detailed events programme by visiting www.historicenvironment.scot visit-a-place whats-on. Membership gets you unlimited access to HES sites, you can find more information at historicdaysawait.scot

title: everton-find-the-grave-of-championship-winning-goalkeeper
story: FOLLOWING an appeal in last weeks paper, heritage researchers have found the grave of the goalkeeper who helped Everton win their first Championship.David Jardine also became the Merseyside clubs first keeper to ever play at Goodison Park in .The son of a stonemason from Dumfriesshire died a cottage between Biggar and Coulter on March , .Everton Heritage Society carry out several research projects each year to locate the graves of prominent former players and hold rededication ceremonies.They have already erected headstones for two other players from north of the Border, Andrew Hannah and Sandy Young, who were buried in unmarked graves.Despite extensive searches around Biggar as well as family plots at Elvanfoot and Applegarth in Dumfriesshire, they couldnt find the grave of David Jardine.And a search had begun in the rural graveyards around Tweeddale.But just hours after we published an appeal, information has led the historical group to the goalkeepers grave - in a church yard that had already been checked.Tony Onslow from Everton Heritage Society told us: "Davids we Sarah is buried at Elvanfoot and we carried out checks which showed he isnt buried with her."But we didnt think to check the rest of the graveyard."We have now received information that hes buried in plot  where as Sarah is in ."We will be travelling up from Liverpool soon to visit his grave."

title: folk-royalty-rolls-into-selkirk
story: HES rightly regarded as folk Royalty.And next week Martin Carthy will show the String Jam Club audience exactly why.If the English folk revival of the s had a father-figure and guiding spirit, then Martin Carthy would be it.As the Letime Achievement Award winner at BBC Radio  Folk Awards in , Martin makes a welcome third visit to String Jam Club on Saturday, April .For more than  years he has been one of folk musics greatest innovators, one of its best loved, most enthusiastic and, at times, most quietly controversial of figures.His skill, stage presence and natural unassuming charm have won him many admirers, not only from within the folk scene, but also far beyond it.String Jam promoter Allie Fox told us: "If you trace Martins career from that period to the modern day, you have perhaps the most important and influential folksinger in England, a source of inspiration for many, a conduit for the songs, a genius guitar player who uses tunings you never knew existed, a model for how to approach traditional music, and in short a legend."In  Martin was awarded an MBE for his services to folk music."This is a wonderful opportunity to see and hear this folk icon live and up close at String Jam Club."Martin has been described as ldquoarguably the greatest English folk song performer, writer, collector and editor of them all by Q Magazine. Hersquos a ballad singer, a ground-breaking acoustic and electric-guitarist and an authoritative interpreter of newly composed material.Perhaps, most signicant of all, are his settings of traditional songs with guitar, which have influenced a whole generation of artists on both sides of the Atlantic, including Bob Dylan who first met Martin in the early s and has described him as ldquoincredible and Paul Simon, who notoriously used Martinrsquos arrangement of lsquoScarborough Fairrsquo for his hit single.Martin has long been regarded as one of the most pivotal figures in the English folk revival of the s, his vocal and guitar style being two of the most consistent, distinctive and influential sounds on the scene.Martin will play at the County Hotel in Selkirk on Saturday, April Doors open at .pm.Tickets, priced at pound, are available online from Eventbrite or in person from the County Hotel. To reserve tickets, email thestringjamclub@gmail

title: council-plans-could-mean-last-orders-for-public-drinkers
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has launched a consultation to gauge public opinion on the drinking of alcohol in public spaces, with the possibility of a byelaw banning public drinking being introduced.Currently, legislation pertaining to public alcohol consumption is decided by local councils, with some enforcing byelaws to prevent drinking in public.The Borders is one council area where public alcohol consumption is not currently outlawed.However, the council are keen to hear from Borderers to establish whether people think the drinking of alcohol in any public areas is causing problems.An online survey will be accessible until May  and the council is keen for locals to voice their opinions on the matter.Paper surveys will also be available in council contact centres and local libraries.If the drinking of alcohol in public places is identied as an issue, a second consultation will take place to understand the level of support for byelaws to be introduced to clamp down on public drinking.If the council did decide to act, they would reserve the right to suspend any byelaw during events such as common ridings, local festivals and new year celebrations.Councillor Shona Haslam, Leader of Scottish Borders Council, said: "As a council we considered this proposition a few years ago but we felt that we needed to hear from local communities before taking this further.ldquoDo you think that they are needed ldquoDo you think that they should be town wide, or specic to certain areas ldquoDo you think that this a necessary or unnecessary step for the Council to take ldquoAny ban would not stop people drinking in their gardens, beer gardens or at licensed events, but we want to know of any potential problem areas that the public think such a ban would be helpful.The online survey, alongside further information about the consultation, can be accessed at https:scotborders.citizenspace

title: borders-bairns-benefit-from-baby-boxes
story: , families in the Borders have benefitted from the delivery of a Baby Box since their introduction in .Across Scotland, over , Baby Boxes have been delivered.The concept of the Baby Box has its roots in Finland and has been shown to decrease infant mortality rates.The boxes themselves double up as a safe place for newborn children to sleep and contain a iety of essential items to help parents care for their babies in the first weeks and months of le.The Scottish government recently announced a new Baby Box design, created by a group of schoolchildren from across Scotland, in time for Motherrsquos Day.SNP MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, Christine Grahame, is delighted that the boxes have proved to be so popular. She said: ldquoEvery child, regardless of their circumstances, should get the best start in le.ldquoAt the heart of the Baby Box is a message about fairness and opportunity, which is why Irsquom delighted to see that  of new families have benefitted from it in the Borders.ldquo% of expectant parents in Scotland are now requesting a Baby Box ndash and more than , have been delivered.ldquoThatrsquos a huge vote of confidence in the Baby Box.ldquoGiven how beneficial they are to parents and newborns, long may that continue.

title: innerleithen-artist-designs-trophies-for-scottish-alpaca-group-championships
story: AN Innerleithen glass crafterrsquos works of art will adorn the mantelpieces of winners in a top nationwide competition.The artist was delighted when she was asked to make the trophies for The Scottish Alpaca Group Championships which take place next month.And glamorous models trotted into Maureen Brandrsquos gallery this week after becoming the inspiration for her latest creation.As she approaches the first anniversary of opening her gallery MB Bespoke Glass in Traquair Road, Maureen casts her mind back to the achievements throughout the year that led her to this most unusual commission.She says: ldquoLots has happened during this time such as working endless hours promoting the crafters who showcase their makes within the shop, but more importantly establishing that my work in stained glass was a quality product made from good workmanship.A defining moment for the crafter was being announced as a finalist in The Scottish Borders Chamber Of Commerce Business Awards last year.It was at this ceremony that Maureen would find her latest project. ldquoThis is where I met Stuart from Velvet Hall Alpacas. We talked about our businesses when I mentioned that I could make trophies for awards ceremonies. Stuart askedI would be able to make the trophies for the Alpaca competition and said it would be great to present a bespoke trophy that was a little dferent.The Scottish Alpaca Group gave Maureen the go-ahead but in order to create the trophy she needed woolly models.ldquoI visited the Alpacas at Velvet Hall so that I could photograph them in lots of dferent angles, capturing their colours, personality and character. This helps me when Irsquom making the design for a piece.After several meetings to discuss the designs, Maureen rolled up her sleeves and got to work on the winning trophies creating  in ious colours for the dferent breeds.She said: ldquoIrsquom thrilled to achieve this commission and hope that the finished products will at least look similar to these fabulous animals.ldquoEnquiries for commissions have increased so much so that I now have a waiting list

title: scottish-borders-council-leader-moves-to-dispel-ipads-criticism
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilrsquos leader has moved to dispel fears about the authorityrsquos new digital learning programme, which includes giving iPads to all secondary school pupils.One of the flagship policies to come out of the Tory Independent alliance   budget is that iPads will be bought for every P to S pupil, which they will be able to take home and use with their family. Devices will also be given to P to P pupils at a ratio of one for every five children, although these will be kept at their school.The project will cost pound.m over a ten-year contract with American technology giant Apple and Canadian firm CGI.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday  March, opposition councillors sought clarication on a number of issues from council leader Shona Haslam.Tweeddale West councillor Heather Anderson asked: how much will it cost to provide wi access for all nine high schools how much of the budget has been set aside for training teachers what targets have been set for teachers and finally, what will be the cost be of charging the iPads, and how will this be achieved Councillor Haslam who represents Tweeddale East, replied: ldquoWi-fi is already available in all Scottish Borders Council schools. The survey work is being contracted via CGI who have appointed a contractor. ldquoThe councilrsquos agreement with CGI is that the initial wi-fi surveys will be completed by the end of April . ldquoConvener, I must admit that I am a bit confused. The opposition and administration both held budget working groups.ldquoBoth groups agreed that this is a good thing to do. It reduces the poverty gap, it improves attainment, it reduces the burden on teachers, and provides digital learning access to ensure our young people are equipped for the future.ldquoAnd yet now the opposition are attempting to grill the administration on this policy. I had assumed that during the budget setting process the opposition were as robust as the administration, but these questions clearly show us that they were not.ldquoWhat is very clear is that the opposition have not read the papers, do not understand the project and are intent on opposing for oppositionrsquos sake.ldquoThis is a policy that last month you supported, that last month was included in your budget, and that last month thought was a great idea.ldquoTrue to form, you think something completely dferent.With regards to teacher training time, Ms Haslam said: ldquoTime has been set aside in the work time agreement for the first year of deployment of five hours dedicated training per teacher. More time will be set aside for training each year. ldquoThese sessions are to be scheduled in non-contact time and no additional cover requirement, or costs is expected.ldquoInspire learning is seen as a way of enhancing the process of teaching and learning, it is not envisaged that there will be a requirement for teachers to transfer existing materials in bulk.ldquoThe iPads can be used to access existing online educational content within glow and they can be used for sharing feedback on pupilrsquos work without the development of new materials.The first iPads will be rolled out to teachers in April , so they can get to grips with them and test out the system.S to S pupils will be the first schoolchildren in the Borders to receive their iPads, which will be handed to them in August .The following year, teachers of P and P pupils will be given iPads in April , and in August of that year the roll out will be extended to P and P pupils, as well as to new S pupils.Neither pupils nor their parents will be able to download apps or games to the iPad, as it will come pre-loaded with the necessary apps.Each iPad will have a block on harmful websites, which will continue even when connected to wi-fi outside of their school. The block will apply no matter which family member is using the iPad.During classes, the teacher will have complete control over each iPad.Ms Haslam continued: ldquoInspire Learning is designed to enhance the delivery of the whole curriculum and best practise will be developed to ensure subject teachers can collaborate effectively. ldquoA major benefit of the integrated learning is that teachers can easily share best practice online accessing a wide range of educational materials and do not having to develop subject specic resources by themselves.ldquoThere will be opportunities in the future for subject staff to collaborate between establishments and to share good practice on cross schools days and network meetings days.The council leader also confirmed that the cost of charging an iPad for educational use will amount to pound per year, and that students will be expected to bring their iPad to school charged each day.

title: budding-performers-sprinkle-some-stardust
story: TALENTED young performers treated their audience to a musical extravaganza in Peebles on Saturday night.The Stardust Musical Theatre Company held its annual showcase to a sold out crowd in the Eastgate Theatre.lsquoA Night at the Musicalsrsquo was a greatest-hits compilation of some of the best-known songs from the world of musical theatre.The Stardust cast sang, acted and danced their way through nearly  great musical numbers.Now in its third year the Peebles cast, aged between five and  years old, moved its showcase up a gear with the most ambitious production to-date.Before the show began the packed audience was treated to a fun creative number replacing the standard audience announcement about safety and concert protocol.Musical number one was the ever popular, Wind in the Willows, where the performers donned animal attire to sing and dance their way over to Toad Hall.The junior and intermediate groups combined to bring this musical number to le. Lilly Jackson played the flamboyant Toad accompanied by Hannah Thurston, Mila Vardanian, and Milena Osinka as Mole, Ratty and Badger.The three pesky stoats played by Kathryn Henderson, Caitlin Thurston and Ava Lukehurst encouraged laughs for their bad behaviour and one liners. What do you get when you cross three stoats and a picnic  A pic nicked.The second act of the night took us to s London for the classic My Fair Lady. A young cockney flower-seller well played by Ruby Thornley swaps street corners for elocution lessons and a ladies day at the races.She is taken under the wing of Professor Higgins, performed by Lila Kitching who had suffered an injury only a week before opening night. Needing to use crutches did not stop her from taking part and impressing the crowd.After a quick interval, we swapped the s for the st century with the seniors channelling the wildcat spirit of High School Musical. Upbeat numbers included Stick to the Status Quo, Breaking Free, and an ambitious, very well performed, basketball number Getrsquocha Head in the Game.Everyone was in the high school spirit thanks to the catchy numbers and teen drama narrated by Niamh Smith.Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was up next as the junior group had every sweet tooth in the house tingling. Rosie Noble charmed the audience as Charlie, the lucky winner of a golden ticket to Willy Wonkarsquos factory.Wonka was performed by Toby Haslam and the narrators were Aimee Morton and Elena Chrystie.Everyonersquos inner rebel cheered along to a stirring performance of School of Rock.The intermediate group took on the role of school children who swap studies for band practice, performing hits such as Stick it to the Man and Yoursquore in the Band.After a spectacular musical experience all the performers took to the stage for the finale. The Stardust students sang The Greatest Showmanrsquos hit This is Me to a roaring applause.Show producer, Fiona Henderson told us: ldquoAll of our Stardust pupils have put in so much work over the last few months as they learnt all their lines, songs and dance routines for their showcase.ldquoIt really paid off in a great performance from everyone and the tutors and I are all very proud of them. Next stop, Broadway.Stardust Cast of :Abigail Harper, Ada Murphy, Aimee Morton, Anna Nethercot, Ava Lukehurst, Beth Johnson, Caitlin Thurston, Coco Turnbull, Eilidh Muir, Elena Chrystie, Emily Roberts, Eve Simpson, Gabriela Hamza, Gabrielle Sellar, Grace Clark, Hannah Paulin, Hannah Thurston, Imogen Smith, Kathryn Henderson, Lila Kitching, Lilly Jackson, Lily Ellis, Megan Cruickshanks, Melina Osinka, Mila Vardanian, Millie Jones, Oliver Johnson, Phoebe Byrne, Rosie Callaghan, Rosie Noble, Ruby Thornley, Sadie Ackerman, Scarlett MacNeil, Sophie Crittenden, Sophie Muir, Taylor Cunningham, Toby Haslam.

title: gattonside-house-redevelopment-given-three-year-extension
story: THE conversion of Gattonside House into residential flats has been put back another three years, following a successful bid by the developers for more time.The Brothers of Charity, a catholic organisation which is headquartered in Rome, received approval from Scottish Borders Council in March  to convert the historic Gattonside building into  flats and to build  houses to the south east of the property.However, negotiations between the developers and council planners for developer contributions took several years to complete, and full planning permission was only granted in December .The Brothers of Charity wanted to reduce the number of affordable housing units down to five, from the required , but a compromise was reached and the developers are set to provide nine affordable housing units.Furthermore, the Brothers of Charity will have to contribute pound, towards education, pound, towards the redevelopment of the Borders railway route, and pound, towards play facilities.The commencement period for the development ran out in February , meaning the developers have had to reapply to Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning department for a three-year extension period.The application was heard by councillors sitting on the councilrsquos planning and building standards committee, which met on Monday  March.Barry Fotheringham, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos principal planning officer, told the committee: ldquoThe principle of development on this land has clearly been established by inclusion in the local development plan.ldquoGiven the suspensive nature of planning conditions, sufficient justication has been made for an additional three year period.ldquoFurthermore, there are no local or national policy constraints that would not support the renewal of consent.ldquoA further listed building consent will be required for the conversion of Gattonside House. This will be considered separately.ldquoI recommend that this application is approved.Councillors were advised that the acceptance of a new section  agreement would be straightforward, as the terms had already been agreed in the previous planning application, and so councillors voted unanimously to approve the three-year commencent period.

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet of the Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, is Cushy.The charity told us: "The lovely Cushy has just turned seven years old and is a retired racing greyhound. Being an ex-racer, Cushy is not really used to living in a home environment, although she has spent a little time in a home before coming to us and she is currently staying in a foster home."Cushy will need a bit house training, although she has been very clean here at the centre."Cushy gets on well with other dogs but she does need a cat-free home."Cushy is a very laid back girl who doesnt need much exercise at all ndash unless cuddles count as exercise!"If you would like to offer Cushy her forever home, please email Borders Pet Rescue on info@borderspetrescue.org for an application."

title: borders-youngsters-elect-new-young-parliament-representatives
story: YOUNG people across the region have learned who will be representing them following the declaration for the Scottish Young ParliamentElections -.All --year-olds from across Scotland were invited to cast their vote to elect a Member of the Scottish Youth Parliamentfor their constituency.The Scottish Borders has two SYP constituencies - Midlothian South, Tweeddale  Lauderdaleand Ettrick, Roxburgh  Berwickshire .With only three candidates electing to stand for the respective seats, an uncontested election ensued.Isabel Headon, S at Peebles High School, was elected to represent the Midlothian South, Tweeddale  Lauderdale constituency.Rhys Pearce, S at Loretto Senior School, Edinburgh, was elected to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh  Berwickshire, with -year-old Tanya Thomson re-elected to the other seat in the constituency.The Scottish Youth Parliament is the democratically elected voice of Scotlands young people, campaigns on a wide range of issues and represents young people all over Scotland.The elected members of the Scottish Youth Parliament hold a two-year term in the position and are expected to represent their constituency by being an active community member as well as attending national Scottish Youth Parliament sittings.Councillor Carol Hamilton, Executive Member for Children and Young People at Scottish Borders Council, welcomed the incoming representatives. She said: ldquoMany congratulations to our newly elected MSYPs on their success, both inidually and as a group.ldquoThey are to be commended for their commitment to putting themselves forward for this unique and privileged position and I am sure they will make the most of the opportunity it gives them to raise awareness about issues affecting both their own lives and those of the people they represent.ldquoI wish them well as they take up their new roles and look forward to working with them and seeing the contribution they make as MSYPs, both at a local and national level.Councillor Hamilton also took time to thank the outgoing MSYPs for their service. She added: ldquoThey are all to be commended for the outstanding way in which they represented the children and young people of the Borders and made such a positive contribution to the Scottish Youth Parliament.

title: thirlestane-wins-wonderful-place-to-stay-gong
story: THIRLESTANE Castle has won a top gong at the UK Heritage Awards.The country house in Lauder scooped the lsquoWonderful Place to Stayrsquo award at the ceremony hosted at Grocerrsquos Hall in London last Monday.Edward Maitland-Carew, resident trustee, said: ldquoAfter what has been an enormous restoration project here at the castle, we are so grateful to receive this recognition.ldquoHaving the ability to accommodate iniduals and groups of up to sixteen people in high-quality accommodation will mean that many more people are able to come and share this beautul corner of the Scottish Borders. We would like to extend our thanks to all those who have been a part of this journey.The UK Heritage Awards are organised by Visit Heritage, the UKrsquos leading heritage, tourism and destination marketing company.The awards had twelve categories, with the addition of the Inidual Award for Contribution to Heritage.The judges  was formed of leading figures and experts on UK Heritage, and it included: Norman Hudson OBE, chairman of the Country Houses Foundation Annie Reilly, manager at Heritage Open Days for the National Trust William Sitwell, Independent Heritage property owner of Weston Hal Jeremy Musson, architectural historian and consultant,Gary Swarbrooke, director of Visit Heritage and Paul Bridle, CEO of Excellence Squared Group.Thirlestane Castle dates back to the th century, when a large Border fort was built on the site to defend the approach to Edinburgh from the south.The central part of the present castle was completed in , remodelled in the s, and then again in the s.Thirlestane is set to open its doors for the  visitor season on April .

title: scottish-borders-council-defends-recycling-performance
story: A PUBLIC awareness campaign is set to be launched in the Borders in a bid to meet recycling targets and reduce waste contamination.Scottish Borders Councilhas defended its recycling performance, following concerns.At a meeting of the council on Thursday, March , the authorityrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure councillor Gordon Edgar fielded questions from concerned opposition councillors.Hawick and Hermitage councillor David Patersonasked: ldquoIs it true that more and more recycling waste is put into landfill by the company we use due to the amount of contamination in the recycling ldquoI am informed that this has increased quite dramatically from previous years and would like to know how much extra this is costing Scottish Borders Council.ldquoDo you not think that this is a real let down for the vast majority of people in the Borders who faithfully recycle Selkirkshire councillor Edgar pointed out that the local authority performs very well against its contamination targets: ldquoThe quantity of contaminated material collected, in terms of the councilrsquos kerbside recycling service, has remained fairly static in recent years at around  per cent.ldquoIn the last  months, the council has only once exceeded the target contamination level outlined in its recycling contract.ldquoContamination is an important factor, and officers are currently developing a communications campaign to increase awareness, reduce contamination and increase recycling rates.ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank the public for their continued support for the councilrsquos waste and recycling service, and ask them to continue to play their part.A Scottish Border Council spokesperson said: ldquoIn  the Scottish Environment Protection Agency indicated that the average contamination of material accepted at material recover facilities is around  per cent but in some cases is as high as  per cent.ldquoBased on this, title: local-msp-investigated-over-non-disclosure-in-holyrood-debate
story: A LOCAL MSP is facing a standards investigation amid claims she criticised the SNPrsquos ldquohigh tax agenda for businesses without declaring she owns a hotel.Rachael Hamilton , who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, made the comments during First Ministerrsquos Questions last year ndash resulting in a complaint to the ethics watchdog.A Holyrood committee will now consider the issue after receiving a report from Bill Thomson, the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Le.Ms Hamilton owns Buccleuch Arms Hotel in St Boswells with her husband Billy and her parliamentary Register of Interests states that she has  per cent of the issued share capital in Borders Hotels Ltd.During FMQs in November, she said: ldquoWe hear today that the number of Scottish retailers going bust is on the rise according to research conducted by French Duncan and, among other cost pressures, a rise in business rates are being blamed.ldquoWhen will the First Minister realise that her Governmentrsquos high tax agenda is punishing our high streets and take urgent action to support Scotlandrsquos retailers The letter of complaint is understood to state: ldquoMs Hamilton has previously made clear that she appreciates the requirement of registering her interest when asking such a question.ldquoBy failing to register her outside interests, Ms Hamilton appears to have failed to comply with the aforementioned section of the MSPsrsquo code of conduct.ldquoI would be gratefulyou could investigate this matter and consider whether there has been a breach.An SNP source told the Border : ldquoThis isnrsquot the first time Rachael Hamilton has used her position as an elected politician to lobby for lower business taxes ndash which her own business would just so happen to benefit from. It should go without saying that politicians should declare any conflict of interest when lobbying on an issue that would affect their own business ndash the rules are perfectly clear.ldquoThe Tories have already seen a frontbencher forced to resign and another sanctioned in Parliament for similar behaviour ndash yoursquod think they would have learned their lesson.We offered Ms Hamilton the opportunity to respond but she declined to do so while the investigation was ongoing.

title: spring-seminar-launches-borders-floral-gateway-contest
story: GREEN-FINGERED community groups turned out in force for the Bordersrsquo first Spring Seminar which helped launch this yearrsquos Floral Gateway competition.The annual contest is judged across from a range of organisations and charities provided information and advice to local groups on a iety of topics including bioersity, sustainable food production and potential funding streams.The seminar reflected on the changes made last year to grass cutting maintenance, the alternatives to bedding plant provision to be made this autumn, and bioersity and new wildflower areas due to be introduced.Groups were given the chance to discuss specic proposals in their communities and creative ideas for the future which was supported by speakers who offered evidence of how groups can play their part.Wilton Lodge Park volunteer co-ordinator, Lisa Brydon, discussed the challenges of introducing food production to the parkrsquos famous walled garden with her army of volunteers.John Wilkinson from the Borders Beekeepers Association explained the benefits of wildflower meadows and reduced grass maintenance for a iety of wildle.Karen Birch of the charity Abundant Borders talked title: calmacs lochranza bonanza
story: So it was on Monday when CalMac#s diesel-electric MV Catriona, one of the newest vessels in the fleet, was brought into service on the Cloanaig to Lochranza run.Its job, almost unbeliveably,  was to alleviate pressure at Ardrossan,  miles away, where a crash caused a smaller vessel to be operating.The super smooth, almost silent ferry, ran a continuous shuttle and judging by the midday sailing immediately became popular.Not everyone had driven round, for some Kintyre folk it offered an easy day out on Arran.A number of Islay and whisky tourists were able to include Lochranza Distillery on their itineraries.This begs the question: Why not upgrade the single-track B between Claonaig and Kennacraig to improve it for winter A year round Cloanaig to Lochranza service may reinvigorate trade between one of Arran#s iconic villages, Skipness, Tarbert, Kintyre and Islay.Springbank and Glen Scotia distilleries have found whisky tourists are not seasonal. title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: mid argyll photo club snaps up trophy
story: Leaving Campbeltown and Carradale trailing, Mid Argyll won the annual Frank Walton competition between all nine Argyll photo clubs for the first time in  years.Cowal and Mid Argyll both scored the same total points but Mid Argyll was declared the winner, having entered the highest scoring inidual image.The top image # scoring   # was In Safe hands Verina Litster’s photo of  baby Nia held by her father Derek Robertson who is a firefighter at Inveraray and Clydebank.Verina also scored joint second highest with Dreich Night in Glasgow, an image that she took on her mobile phone.Helen Phillip was joint rd with Café Le giving the club a st, nd and rd placing.See all MACC entries at  http:www.macc.ukphotographers -fwcomp.htmlOn Thursday evening, March , about fty amateur photographers from across Argyll and Bute braved the wild weather, many making a long detour to Arrochar due to the A being closed overnight at Inveraray.The competition was hosted this year by the Three Villages Camera Club in the Three Villages Hall in Arrochar.A record number of nine Argyll photo clubs entered this year, demonstrating the upsurge of enthusiasm for improving digital images through friendly competition for the Frank Walton Argyll Inter-club Trophy.The Bute Photographic Society was added to clubs in Campbeltown, Carradale, Cowal, Helensburgh, Mid-Argyll, Oban, Peninsulaand Three Villages.Each club submitted  images from each club to be judged by Neil McGregor of the Kirkintilloch Camera Club.Neil made useful comments on each of the  images, with encouraging suggestions for improvement rather than criticism.The trophy was donated in  by Frank Walton, the photographer who had the camera shop in Oban, and the last time Mid Argyll won the cup was back in  when it was a slide competition.The clubs take turns to organise the event in their home towns. The next competition will be held in Dunoon in March .Scores out of : Mid Argyll CC , Cowal CC , Peninsula CC  , Oban Photographic Club , Helensburgh Digital Photography Club , Campbeltown CC , Bute Photographic Society , Carradale CC , Three Villages CC .In Safe hands Verina Litster’s photo of baby Nia held by her father Derek Robertson who is a firefighter at Inveraray and Clydebank.
